page.title: Promoting Critical Thinking With Beginning-Level Adult ELLs
page.contents:
It may not look like critical thinking at first glance . . .
but even in this beginning-level lesson on map-reading, this classroom teacher, Carol Margolis, a teacher at More School in St. Paul MN, adds a layer of critical thinking.

Optional Task: Print the Video Observation Form: Beginning Class and note the task type and the thinking skills practiced during each stage of the lesson.

page.title: Debriefing the Video
page.contents:
Components of higher-order thinking in Carol's lesson:

  • More complex calendar questions
  • Learner-generated quiz questions
  • Organizing information to show relationships
  • Restructuring as new information is given
  • Making decisions based on what learners hear and see
  • Identifying, evaluating, and synthesizing information from written and verbal instructions

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT4_0190.mp3

Audio transcript


Learners like Aadan, Inez, and Carlos have resided in the United States for a long time. Often adult ELA programs focus on topics that could be considered quite basic. Regardless of their language level, learners most likely have interests much like your own. Imagine you were transported to another country and enrolled in a language class. Would you rather learn about holidays or differences regarding deep cultural values and beliefs? When learning about transportation, would you appreciate learning about the benefits of public transportation to the community rather than only learning about how to read a bus schedule? Rich content mirrors content students may encounter in academic settings. This table suggests content you could use to supplement typical topics you might find in your existing curriculum. Let’s see how the theme of parenting can include critical discussion of managing social media in the lives of families.

page.title: Social Media Pre-activity 1
page.contents:
Let’s see now the theme of parenting can include critical discussion of managing social media in the lives of families.

Ask learners:

  1. What comes to mind when you hear the word "social media"?
  2. Share those ideas with a partner and sort your ideas into categories (any you see).
  3. Present those to another group; find similarities and differences.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT4_0200.mp3

Audio transcript


What critical thinking skills are promoted in this pre-activity? There’s categorizing, comparing and contrasting, and predicting and analyzing the issue, all in a simple previewing task.

Audio transcript


Using a Jigsaw Approach, which is demonstrated in Unit 3, each group is in charge of a different video and topic. The video clips are around 2 minutes long and the concrete listening task makes these authentic videos accessible to adult ELLs. Once everyone has completed their section, they compare with others in the same group and discuss some possible solutions of their own. Finally, they make new groups and present their findings to others in the class. A final assignment could be to identify the big ideas across the three videos and synthesize those in a writing assignment. This example serves to demonstrate what you could do with a number of different issue-related themes: housing, transportation, environmental issues, health, education. Can you think of some others?

page.title: Creating a Critical Thinking Mindset: Steps 1 and 2
page.contents:
This activity from John Hughes, a teacher and textbook author, helps set expectations for the kind of thinking you hope to see in your classes.

Step 1: Write a statement on the board, for example:

Cell phones should be prohibited in schools.

Step 2: Students think of their response to that statement.

From Hughes, J. (2014)

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT4_0220.mp3

Audio transcript


In Part I of this unit, we looked at qualities of critical thinkers, for example, they are curious and they ask questions. They seek evidence to support a claim. In his article, Steps to Critical Thinking, John Hughes proposes an activity for creating a critical thinking mindset. Start by writing a statement on the board about which students may have an opinion. Students think of their response to that statement. Next, show them a list of the statements that follow.

page.title: Creating a Critical Thinking Mindset: Step 3
page.contents:
Step 3: Provide the possible answers, and students select the one closest to their own:

  1. I'm not interested in this topic.
  2. I agree. It's true.
  3. I disagree. It's false.
  4. I'm not sure.
  5. I agree up to a point, but I also disagree.
  6. I agree/disagree because ....
  7. I agree/disagree for a number of reasons, but I'd also like more evidence.

Which are the words of a critical thinker?

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT4_0230.mp3

Audio transcript


Look at these responses and think about or discuss what they show about the mindset of the learner. Once learners choose the closest statement, they learn what it means in terms of critical thinking.

page.title: Creating a Critical Thinking Mindset: Step 4
page.contents:
Step 4: Show this key to learners:

IF YOU SAID . . .

  1. I'm not interested in this topic.
    You don't need to be interested to have an opinion.
  2. I agree. It's true.
  3. I disagree. It's false.
    Can you give reasons for your strong opinion?
  4. I'm not sure. (formatting issue – don't indent)
  5. I agree up to a point, but I also disagree.
    This is safe, but critical thinkers are active in a discussion.
  6. I agree/disagree because ....
    Good, you have a reason for your opinion.
  7. I agree/disagree for a number of reasons, but I'd also like more evidence.
    Great! You have reasons and you want to know more! That's a critical thinker!

page.title: Creating a Critical Thinking Mindset
page.contents:
The activity for creating a critical thinking mindset serves to:

  • Define critical thinking for learners
  • Demonstrate what it looks like
  • Hold learners responsible for engaging critically

Revisit with students throughout a course. Let them evaluate their own development as critical thinkers!

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT4_0240.mp3

Audio transcript


This activity for creating a critical thinking mindset serves to define critical thinking for learners; it also demonstrates what it looks like and, in some ways, holds learners responsible for engaging critically in classroom conversations. This task can be revisited with students throughout a course, and they can evaluate their own development as critical thinkers! Let’s turn to the language needed to clearly express those ideas in English.

page.title: Fortifying Our Language
page.contents:
Hand in hand with a critical thinking mindset is interaction.

Learners need to build on their existing ideas and clarify their knowledge when interacting with others. They need to strengthen their ideas (Zwiers, 2014).

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT4_0250.mp3

Audio transcript


Jeff Zwiers suggests that many common activities do a good job of generating output, for example, jigsaw activities, mingles. or information gap tasks, but do they always lead to real interactions? He says that output often consists of one-way, one-time communication, often not much more than one or two sentences. Interactions, on the other hand, are back-and-forth exchanges of output where learners build on one another’s ideas; they build up and clarify knowledge that wasn’t in their minds before talking. He argues that we need to help learners to bulk-up or fortify learner output.

page.title: How Can We Fortify Learner Output?
page.contents:
Opinion Formation Cards:

  • Provide evidence for formulating an opinion
  • Allow learners to analyze and refine their opinions
  • Fortify output as students add to pre-existing beliefs

Read the directions and opinion formation cards. What critical thinking skills will this activity promote and how will it fortify learner output? Share ideas with your colleagues.

Children should not be allowed to watch TV.

  • A study showed that children who watch TV engage in more violent behaviors.
  • A survey showed that children who watched educational shows began to read sooner.

From Common Core Standards in Diverse Classrooms Jeff Zwiers, Susan O’Hara, and Robert Pritchard, copyright © 2014, reproduced with permission of Stenhouse Publishers. www.stenhouse.com 

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT4_0260.mp3

Audio transcript


Here’s one example of how to fortify language from the Academic Language Development Network. Sheets of opinion cards are copied on different colors, cut up and distributed. Cards provide different sides of the issue and evidence to support them. Students talk to several students, each time gaining more data and evidence to potentially adjust their opinions.

page.title: Providing the Supports They Need!
page.contents:
Elaborate and Clarify

How so?
What do you mean by...
What makes you think that?
Why is that important?

Synthesize Conversations

We can say that...
We all agree that...

Paraphrase Ideas

It sounds like...
In other words...

Build on a Partner's Idea

I would add that...

Challenge a Partner's Idea

Another way to look at it is...

Support Ideas with Examples

In their book, Academic Conversations, Zwiers and Crawford (2011) identify the core communication skills needed to engage in and sustain academic conversations, for example:

  • Elaborate and Clarify
  • Support ideas with examples
  • Paraphrase ideas
  • Build on and challenge a partner's opinion
  • Synthesize conversations

Excerpt used with permission of the author, Susan Finn Miller whose work was adapted with permission from work by Jeff Zwiers, Copyright 2014.

Visit Unit 1 for more ideas on building academic language learners need for these critical conversations.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT4_0270.mp3

Audio transcript


In their book, Academic Conversations, Zwiers and Crawford (2011) identify the core communication skills needed to engage in critical conversations, for example, they need to elaborate and clarify, support ideas with examples, paraphrase ideas, build on and challenge a partner’s opinion, and synthesize conversations. All of this language goes hand in hand with critical thinking. We need to make these language functions explicit to adult ELLs:

  • Model the language needed
  • Provide sentence frames
  • Post the phrases on the board/wall
  • Provide academic conversation starters

This list contains more language for starting those conversations and maintaining them. There are several phrases offered for each language function. Language functions are those social purposes for using language, so you’ll find several different ways we can express an opinion, agree, or disagree in English. Choose phrases that are manageable for the level you serve. Make posters, give sentence starters on flashcards, post them on the board, make them part of oral assessments.

page.contents:
What to say when you disagree:

  • Then again, we shouldn't forget...
  • I see it differently, based on...
  • That's a valid point, but I think...
  • I understand the idea of...but I think that...
  • On the other hand...
  • I do agree with the part about...but..

Excerpt used with permission of the author, Susan Finn Miller whose work was adapted with permission from work by Jeff Zwiers, Copyright 2014

ELL_MOD1_UNIT4_0290.mp3

Audio transcript


Drawing on the work of Jeff Zwiers, Susan Finn Miller provides adult ELA educators with Academic Conversation Starters like this one. What to say when… cards. See how much more expressive a student becomes when they move beyond “I think or I feel.” These conversation starters can go hand in hand with any of the activities in this unit.

page.title: Let’s Review the Principles
page.contents:
• Critical thinking can and should be practiced at all levels of instruction.
  • Add critical thinking as a layer to all lessons.
  • Ask questions that prompt critical thinking.
  • Teach the language needed to express students' ideas.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT4_0300.mp3

Audio transcript


Before you complete a final application activity, let’s review some key ideas from Unit 4. Critical thinking can and should be practiced at all levels of instruction. You can do this by adding a layer of critical thinking to existing activities, lessons, and curricula. Create lessons with multiple possible answers or that require a level of analysis. Use graphic organizers to show the relationship between ideas. Ask questions that go beyond recall. Use the Depth of Knowledge wheel as you are planning instruction. Make sure you are moving up to levels 3 and 4 and that you are guiding students toward a critical thinking mindset.

page.title: Application for Teachers
page.contents:
Choose a lesson you currently teach and add a layer of critical thinking. Try to make at least three modifications to an existing lesson. You could do any of the following:

  • Create questions to prompt critical thinking
  • Create a task for applying any critical thinking skills: comparing and contrasting, challenging ideas
  • Use a graphic organizer
  • Provide necessary language frames
  • Share your lesson modification with your colleagues

This lesson analysis template might help you with your planning.

page.contents:
